column1: Still's disease is a severe version of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), which occurs in children.
Fewer than 1 out of 100,000 people develop adult-onset Still's disease each year.
Almost all people with the disease will have fever, joint pain, sore throat, and a rash.
Often, people with the condition have morning stiffness of joints that lasts for several hours.
The health care provider will use a stethoscope to listen for changes in the sound of your heart or lungs.
The following blood tests can be helpful in diagnosing adult Still's disease: - Complete blood count (CBC), may show a high number of white blood cells and reduced number of red blood cells.
The goal of treatment for adult Still's disease is to control the symptoms of arthritis.
Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, are most often used first.
Such medicines include: - Methotrexate - Anakinra (interleukin-1 receptor agonist) - Tocilizumab (interleukin 6 inhibitor) - Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) antagonists such as Enbrel (etanercept)
Complications may include: - Arthritis in several joints - Liver disease - Pericarditis - Pleural effusion - Spleen enlargement
Call your health care provider if you have symptoms of adult-onset Still's disease.
